course.subject: CORE
course.name: Cognitive Foundations of University Education: Critical Thinking and Data Literacy
course.description: This course provides an introduction to critical thinking and data literacy. Students will be equipped with critical tools to analyse problems of reasoning, evaluate the truthfulness of evidence, examine the fallacies of thinking, as well as the ability to construct valid arguments and reasonable solutions for their personal and professional life.

reviews.author: Ztar
reviews.title: Bad grade (only 25% A range) but good course for year 1
reviews.comment_content:
Lectures:
Module 1: Arguments
Module 2: Reasonings
Module 3: Fallacies
Module 4: Cognitive Bias

Tutorials:
Module 1: Business
Module 2: Science and Technology
Module 3: Personal Life and Society

Copied from Paco Tsang

Personally I think the content is quite useful for year 1 students. It overlaps with some of the contents in MGMT and HUMA courses that will be studied later, such as MGMT2010. Quite recommend to take if you are not aiming for A+.
reviews.comment_teaching: If you actually participate in lectures and tutorials while understanding the course materials, you won't find it boring. Personally I talk with my friends about the materials and answer the questions from professors. Also I did try to answer 'fun' answers to the questions to make it more interesting, but please do this at your own risk as I don't find some of the professors and students entertained. You may result in a participation grade that is lower than those answering normal but boring answer.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not to expose my grade
In-lecture Pop Quizzes: 5%
Mid-term Quiz (Open book with cheatsheet): 15%
Two essays: 40%
Final Exam: 25%
Class Participation: 15%
For a score slightly above the UQ you will get an A-. Not that good but I would say it was enough. Note that the essays actually accounted for most of your grade, so try your best to score 19~20 for each in order to secure an A.( Although it depends a lot on your luck)
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not heavy at all and I would say it was slight indeed, just 2 essays for the tutorials and you need to make good use of ChatGPT( Copilot may be better with the ambiguous grading criteria) The midterm is just 25 MCs while the final exam is short questions that you have to use what you learnt throughout the course. It is quite similar to LS if you are DSE students (Bye bye LS for students from 2025). Also note that both the midterm and final are open book but I would recommend you memorising all materials as your cheatsheet may not include all the stuff and you missed some detail. ( For instance I mess up the if A then B and no A then no B stuff, losing 1 question in the midterm, showing if no full mark in midterm then no A+, so be extra careful with that). Do learn how to apply those concepts and you can ace the final. (Doesn't mean an A+)

reviews.author: Elif
reviews.comment_content:
The content was so-so. It was simple, there were some interesting parts here and there, mostly depends on the instructor.
Lectures 1st half semester
1. Argumentation
2. Reasoning
3. Fallacies
4. Cognitive bias
Tutorials 2nd half-semester
1. Personal Life and Society
2. Science and Technology
3. Business
reviews.comment_teaching: Personally, I think the common lecture, the business module and the personal life & society module were the best. I didn't enjoy the science and technology module that much, but for the sake of the other sections, I'll give it a high rating. One thing is that the teaching isn't directly related to the assignments in the modules, since the TAs are in charge of the essays and the professors just determine the content by themselves, so it is a bit subjective.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading breakdown is:
Participation 15%
Quiz: 15%
Final exam: 25%
Two essays: Each 20%
Pop-up quiz: 5%

My grades for reference:
Participation 14.38%
Quiz: 14%
Final exam: 22%
Two essays: One 16% the other 20%
Pop-up quiz: 5% (everyone gets full marks)

In the end, I got an A. I would say the grading is a bit confusing since the participation points are overly specific and nobody got full marks. Even though I went to and talked in every class I couldn't get the highest mark so I don't know what they consider. The midterm and final exams did not have enough practice and we didn't know how it would be right until we got the papers.
On the other hand, the essay grading was the most clearly understandable one and I feel like I could improve my second essay thanks to the feedback from the first one.
reviews.comment_workload: Almost not workload, two short essays with plenty of time and two exams that have the same topics. You should barely spend any time studying or working on this course, would recommend it. You just have to show up for every class, so maybe don't take the 9 am one, but other than that, pretty easy.

reviews.author: eleanorr
reviews.title: good grade course if you like writing essays, no final exam, no memorization is needed
reviews.comment_content: refer to others
reviews.comment_teaching: all profs are generally quite nice.
reviews.comment_grading:
you can get A+ if you know the game of this course

attendance: attend all lectures, raise up your hands to answer questions for all tutorials (1-2 times / lecture is enough)

quiz: there was one quiz this sem, one-page cheat sheet was allowed, not too hard and the median was quite high

essays (x2): got full marks for both, try to use more concepts in class and write until the word limit. the structure of essay also matters. overall, i think you dont really hv to spend super long time on the essays, just chatgpt the general idea and write it on your own

final quiz: very easy, you can bring cheat-sheet. just list out the concept and elaborate / blow water. no need to recite anything
reviews.comment_workload:
very very little. no final exam. no need to recite anything.

must attend lessons though, you cant ask ur friends to help take attendance as you have to answer questions in lessons for attendance.

light workload if you are good in writing essays.

reviews.author: sheldolololo
reviews.title: Absolute trash grading for a decently fun course
reviews.comment_content:
just a bunch of stuff about cognitive biases, heuristics, assertion, deduction etc. etc.

it’s pretty interesting if you are into philosophy and I learned a lot about the type of arguments I see day to day. I don’t know how useful they are but it’s fun to know i guess.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Jenny was a good professor and I understood the content clearly during class. She also replies to my emails with enthusiasm and is super responsive and helpful. Honestly, one of the most if not the most helpful prof in UST I’ve known so far.

Jeevan was definitely my favourite tutor and I could actually use what I learnt in class because the practices are similar to the final exam. The other two were ok but I honestly don’t really know what the direct connection is to daoism with the course, it’s quite hard to connect the two but fun to listen to i guess.
reviews.comment_grading:
THE ABSOLUTE WORST PART OF THIS COURSE. If you took IB or are a great writer then congratulations, you are set for the essay part but if you are decent/bad, expect a meh grade or a poor one.

As I’m sure other people have also mentioned, participation is ALL THAT MATTERS! 2h commute to my 9am classes of course resulted in me missing a few classes so my grade tanked. To top it off, when you do speak (bc it is a MUST to get the participation grade) during class, the TA doesn’t even look at you a lot of the times or sometimes, I barely even see them so who’s even keeping track?? You can’t even see your grade after every class to be alert so you are forced to accept whatever outcome you get.
reviews.comment_workload: Having to read beforehand is a little bit annoying when you are a busy stem student and not used to it but it’s not the end of the world. Besides, the pieces are pretty interesting to read. Just 2 essays to do and you get a good amount of time to finish them as well, I just procrastinated and did poorly on one of them which was totally my fault.

reviews.author: krm919
reviews.comment_content:
This course about critical thinking will teach you some logical reasoning to help you analyze the situation. If you love to read cases and critical thinking, this is the course you should go to.
Lectures (Before Midterm)
1. Argumentation
2. Reasoning
3. Fallacies
4. Cognitive bias
Tutorials (After Midterm) (Taught by different tutors)
1. Personal Life and Society
2. Science and Technology
3. Business
reviews.comment_teaching:
The first part of this course was the lectures taught by Professor Jenny. She was pretty good at encouraging the class to participate in the lesson. Her slides often include some interesting pictures or questions to help you stay engaged.

The second part was the tutorial part. Overall, the tutors were very fun to talk to and I enjoyed their lessons very much.
reviews.comment_grading:
The content is not difficult. Therefore, the mean average will be very HIGH. If you only read the slides, you cannot get an excellent grade here. I would say it is easy to get a fair grade but difficult to get a good grade.

In-lecture Quizzes: 5%
Mid-term Quiz (Open book): 15%
Two Essays: 20% X2
Final Examination: 25%
Class Participation: 15%
I went below the mean in the midterm and above the mean in the two essays and final exam, my overall grade in the end was B.

It is quite important to be active in the lessons as it will count towards your class participation mark, simply attending the lessons cannot get the full 15%
reviews.comment_workload:
I think the workload in this course is fair because we only need to write 2 essays between 500-1000 words, or sometimes read some cases (depending on which tutor teaches you). Although there are some in-class quizzes, most of them are very easy, you can answer them without doing any revision as long as you attend the lessons.
However, to get an exceptional grade like A range in this course, you need to fully understand the definition of different logical reasoning and fallacies and you need to be able to adopt them in different circumstances.

reviews.author: Yunximeng
reviews.comment_content: Quite simple: definitions, practices, and evaluations. For those who did IB TOK, this course is kind of for you, so long as you are fine with poor grading.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Jenny is really good—engaging, enthusiastic, and clear in classes,, and Prof. Meike and Zheng are fine, although Zheng was harsh on grading.

I do not want to spare a single word in describing the teaching of Marshal (well, although I already had). One bad teaching will undermine the whole course expereience. Therefore, please kindly receive a C from me.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid and final are easy, questions clear and straightforward. If you did IB TOK, you can expect high marks.

The two essays (40% of your final grade), however, are despicable, for the grading is abominably subjective and completely backfires the purported 'critical thinking' practice.

One will also find the attendance mark bewildering as professors do not tell you the criteria thereof.
reviews.comment_workload:
The two essays do require you to think carefully. I didn't.

Otherwise, the workload is fair.

reviews.author: Charles.k
reviews.title: Fun course, not clear grading.
reviews.comment_content:
This course introduce a lot of biases and heuristics. It is quite fun to learn.
And in different tutorial modules, we study different case studies. it is quite fun to learn.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I think most lecturers do a good job in teaching.
The class itself is interactive. We are encouraged to try answer the question.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is not that bad, but very unclear.

Grading scheme:
In-lecture Pop Quizzes (after add-drop) 5%
Mid-term Quiz (Open book) (11 Oct 2023) 15%
Two Essays 20%X2
Final Examination (29 Nov 2023) 25%
Class Participation 15%

One of my essay got full mark and one got 11/20 nearly the minimum. But I didn't receive any feedback about it.
Pop quizzes and mid-term is easy. Most people get high mark.
I go for the paper review session for final exam, at least I receive some comments.
I am quite active in class, so I get good grades in this part.

Final grade: B+, not bad, but still very unclear grading scheme
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not very high, but also not little.
Most tutorial need us to read the materials and some of it are very difficult to read. No need to mention the essays, they required hours of research and writing.

reviews.comment_teaching: Tutorials are great in the sense that you can interact with the instructors and share your thoughts and opinions in a friendly and stress-free environment. I find it very rewarding to attend tutorials as I feel fully engaged and can chat with the instructors. But the lectures are boring af and most importantly, I don't know how will the content be examined in the midterm and final (yes, the final is on the content of the lectures, not Tutorials}
reviews.comment_grading:
Pop-up Quiz: must obtain full marks 5/5

Attendance: 9.6/15 (although I have always interacted and participated in class)

Midterm: 9.6/15 (LQ: 12, mean: 12.54, UQ: 13.8)

Final: 15/25 (LQ: 14.13, mean: 16.77, UQ: 20)

Business Essay: 16/20 (LQ: 12, mean: 13.3, UQ: 15.5)

S&T: 12/20 (LQ: 13, mean: 14.75, UQ: 17) --> sampled from last sem A range sample

Overall: C+

Ps. felt like walking into a battlefield blind without any sample questions on the midterms and final, unclear and diverse grading system
reviews.comment_workload:
Since this course is quite new, there are a few things to bear in mind
1) Everything changes: In the 2022-2023 fall, students are required to hand in three essay assignments, yet, for this semester, we are required to hand in two assignments of our own choice and attend one midterm and one final examination, not what I was expecting at the beginning of the course.

2) Change in TA and instructors: I think Prof Tobias Zurn is quite new to this course cuz I cannot tag him on the instructor list but he brings a lot into the classroom. Main Instructor Jenny is not teaching next semester (as I checked on class quotas as at date of publish)

reviews.author: Ovaltine
reviews.title: IB TOK again
reviews.comment_content: The first 6 weeks are lectures with Professor Nam in a lecture theater that includes cognitive biases and fallacies in critical thinking.  For the last 6 weeks, the class has been split to do tutorials on applying the lecture content in different modules.  (Business, S&T, and personal life and society)
reviews.comment_teaching:
In my opinion, the first 6 weeks are a bit boring and lectures do feel quite long, but it's quite chill and Professor Nam makes the class more fun by using Mentimeter.

The tutorials in the last 6 weeks are more engaging where students are expected to participate and work in groups to answer problems and analyze case studies.    

Business Module
I had Professor Jeevan for the business module, he was very good at teaching the content and getting students to participate in discussions.  His instructions r always clear and his classes are interesting.  However, if you don't raise your hand up in his class, you may get a deduction in participation points.

S&T module
Professor Robin was very friendly in class and the TA often liked to discuss their opinions and views on the class topic with student groups.  Sometimes his class is hard to follow but he will always be open to questions at the end of the lecture.

Personal life and Society Module
Professor Wenjuan teaches his module by requiring students to interact with those they have not spoken to and also encourages students to speak in front of the class.  She is quite supportive, especially when introverts speak up in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading in this course is quite nice,  
2 Quizzes (first 6 weeks)  12.5% x 2
Participation 15%
Essays  20% x 3

Quizzes are on the lecture content that is taught in the first 6 weeks.  These are open book and open discussions, which means that most people get really high marks.

Participation is graded on tutorial participation.  This is graded differently depending on the professor.

Essays are case study analysis questions that you get in every module where you have to apply and explain fallacies and cognitive biases within a given example.

My grades
Quiz 1: 8/12.5 (I did it at home and screwed up :) )
Quiz 2; 12.5/12.5

Business Essay 17/20
S&T Essay 16.5/20
Personal life essay 16/20

Unknown participation

Overall A -
reviews.comment_workload:
First 6 weeks there is basically no work at all.  

Essays can be a bit annoying to do especially during exam seasons, but if you are good at writing OR did IB TOK then it should be no problem.

reviews.author: clt
reviews.comment_content:
This is an optional common core course. You get to learn about some cognitive biases, fallacies and heuristics that we use every day, as well as a (limited) introduction to formal logic. You also get to ~pirate~read a book for free.
Tutorials are basically a rehashing of the lectures, but supported with some more in-class examples. A good primer for the course would be "Logic" by PhilosophyTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q8NVy00tfdI
reviews.comment_teaching:
We get 6 weeks of lectures, then another 3x2 weeks for 3 professors in the following areas: Business, Personal Life and Society, Science and Technology.
Lectures were basically to motivate the points given in the book with engagement and examples, and Prof Nam tries to engage the room with mentimeters.
Prof Nam is amiable, but sometimes crowd control gets difficult with the chaotic anonymity of mentimeter questions.
Engagement in the tutorials depends on the professors. Prof Jaisingh produced an environment with more students participating compared to others (I'm assuming because he didn't count attendance as participation?)

Their respective styles are:
- Prof Jaisingh: brainstorming, high class participation
- Prof Ma: group discussion with TA/himself joining in each group
- Prof Zheng: kahoot-ish quiz followed by info-dump after each question + group discussion
reviews.comment_grading:
Class Participations - 15%
Written Assignments - 3 x 20%
MC Quizzes - 25%
Absolute grading, class participation is graded during the tutorials.
MC Quizzes were open book, open discussion, open internet on the whims of the higher-ups. You can't not get a good score on the quizzes.
Written Assignments are based on rubric attached below.
reviews.comment_workload:
Zero in the first 6 weeks (lectures are optional, so is the reading material)
It starts to ramp up in the following weeks with the roughly biweekly essays, but it was manageable.

Writing assignments are 500-1000 words, mostly because you need that much to convince the graders you understand the concepts. Identify and explain 3-4 concepts by using examples in the text and you're most of the way there.
My first word salad got a pretty high grade, but I will see if that trend continues.

reviews.author: professorwok
reviews.title: Good grade if Professor Nam is teaching!
reviews.comment_content:
As an optional common core course, it is surprisingly interesting and useful. You learn basic critical thinking skills such as reasoning, detecting fallacies and biases, and reconstructing arguments.

It's very satisfying when you apply the concepts you learn and start roasting individuals and organisations within the case studies

Reading Material: Critical Thinking: Your Guide to Effective Argument, Successful Analysis and Independent Study

Course Schedule:
Week 1-6: Lectures
Module 0. Introduction (Introduction)
Module 1. Argumentation (Chapter 1-2)
Module 2. Reasonings (Chapter 3-5)
Module 3. Fallacies (Chapter 8, 10)
Module 4. Cognitive Biases (Chapter 9,11)

Week 7-12: Tutorials
4 lectures (2 weeks) on each of the 3 modules; Personal Life and Society, Business, and Science and Technology

These tutorials just focus on apply the concepts you learnt in the specific field... nothing much but it can be a stimulus for when you write assignments.

Week 13: Focus Group
Review essay writing tips, q&a session with Professor Nam
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Nam uses a lot of witty jokes and examples when teaching. His local accent shouldn't be a problem, but do try count how many times he says 'okay'. He's very approachable and encourages class interaction both in person and on mentimeter.

He also likes to joke that he studied the two most useless Ph subjects; Physics and Philosophy (don't ask him why).

I do find that he is easily distracted from reading (funny) mentimeter responses though.

In tutorials they have professors from the respective departments. It was sometimes boring but it depends on the professor.

Grading participation was very awkward. The TA acts like the class president and just runs around ticking people who spoke in class (it's ridiculous).
reviews.comment_grading:
According to Professor Nam, it is absolute grading. He also emphasises on how HKUST changed its grading policy and bell curve grading is removed (I don't believe this at all!!!)

Overall good grading, getting mean is B, and scoring upper quartile in essay is easily A range. Percentage matters, and you can lose a sub-letter grade for losing 1-2% overall...

1. Tutorial Participations - 15%, 5% each (/5)
You can earn mark for answering questions, presenting as a group and attendance. Each module counts participation separately

2. Written Assignments - 60%. 20% each (/20)
500-1000 words per assignment on each module. You pick 1 case study or topic and analyse the critical thinking flaws within it.

Personal Life & Society - Mean: 13.45/20, Median: 14, Upper Quartile: 16
Business - Mean: 15.14, Median: 15.5, Upper Quartile: 17
Science and Technology - Mean: 13.7, Median: 14, Upper Quartile: 15.5

3. MC Quizzes - 25%, 12.5% each (/12.5)
They are open book and open discussion. The questions are quite tricky so take extra caution on the semantics. The format is 1 hour, 5 T/F (worth 0.5 each) and 10 MCs (worth 1 each).

Quiz 1. Module 1-2, Mean 10.95/12.5, Median: 11.5
Quiz 2: Module 3-4, Mean 12.08/12.5, Median: 12.5

The mean for Quiz 2 is so high because someone hijacked the microphone and started screaming out the answers. Professor Nam does not care!
reviews.comment_workload:
For the first half of the course, there's almost zero workload and the reading material isn't even necessary. Professor Nam's ppt provide more than enough examples. I did not do any revision...

The second half of the course include 3 essays, each 500-1000 words. It isn't so bad but they only upload the assignment after completing the module. They do give close to 2-3 weeks per assignment thouugh.
